prompt: Facts: The deceased, Neelam Bai, was married to the respondent, Babulal, approximately one year prior to the incident.; On 21.05.1997, Neelam Bai consumed poison (Sulfas tablets) at her matrimonial home in Village Kharkhedi, District Shajapur, Madhya Pradesh.; She was taken to the Primary Health Centre, Kalapipal, and later referred to District Hospital, Shajapur.; A Dying Declaration (Ex. P-15) was recorded by the Executive Magistrate (Naib Tehsildar), PW-11, at the District Hospital on 21.05.1997 at around 7:30 PM.; In the dying declaration, Neelam Bai alleged that her husband, Babulal, used to beat her after consuming liquor and harass her, demanding a motorcycle, which led her to consume poison.; Dr. B.S. Kothari (PW-10) was present during the recording and certified her fitness to give the statement *after* it was recorded.; Neelam Bai died on 22.05.1997.; Post-mortem examination confirmed death due to poisoning.; FIR was registered, and Babulal was charged under Section 306 IPC.; Key prosecution witnesses included: PW-1 (father), PW-2 (mother), PW-3 (brother), PW-4 (uncle), PW-5 (neighbor), PW-7 (brother-in-law), PW-10 (Doctor), PW-11 (Executive Magistrate), PW-12 (Investigating Officer).; The Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Shajapur) convicted Babulal under Section 306 IPC and sentenced him to 5 years Rigorous Imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000/-.; The High Court of Madhya Pradesh, Indore Bench, acquitted Babulal, primarily disbelieving the dying declaration due to lack of prior fitness certification by the doctor and minor discrepancies.; The State of Madhya Pradesh filed an appeal against the acquittal in the Supreme Court. | IPC: Section 306 (Abetment of Suicide), Section 107 (Abetment - referenced for definition), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband or Relatives of Husband - elements relevant for establishing cruelty leading to suicide, though not formally charged)
